newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai hosts games for mentally retarded.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai hosts games for mentally retarded.

text.p: About 750 athletes from 15 countries will take part in the first Asia-Pacific Olympics for mentally retarded people which opens in Shanghai on Friday, organisers said on Thursday.

It is the first time in the 28-year history of the Special Olympics movement for mentally retarded people that such an event will take place in Asia, Timothy Shriver, president and chief executive officer of Washington-based Special Olympics International, said by telephone in Shanghai.

The competitors will take part in 24 events in five sports -- track and field, basketball, soccer, swimming and table tennis -- with the opening ceremony on Friday in the 18,000-seat Shanghai stadium to be broadcast on nationwide television.
Deng Pufang, disabled son of paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, is due to attend the opening ceremony.
The competitors come from Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Nepal Bangladesh, Japan, India, Indonesia, South Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and China.
"It was the initiative of the Chinese organising committee that led to this event," Shriver said. "It was their initiative to host these games."
"This means a whole new dawn of opportunity for people in China with mental retardation, who account for from one-and-a-half to five percent of the population," he said.
"If you take a conservative two percent, you have 20 million people in China," he said. "Mental retardation is the largest disability in the world."
The Special Olympics was founded in 1968 in the U.S. by Eunice Kennedy Shriver and is a year-round programme of sports training and competition for individuals with mental retardation.
One million athletes in nearly 150 countries train and compete in 23 summer and winter sports.
